questions.question: The narrative point of view (POV) is:

choices.answer: the main idea of a story.
a hologram in deep space.
the perspective from which the narrator tells a story.
completely unnecessary.
informational literature.
a story.
persuasive.
argumentative.

questions.question: First person narration uses the words:

choices.answer: me / we / us.
he / she / it.
Is this really important?
you / your / yours.

questions.question: Second person narration uses the words:

choices.answer: you / yours.
This is the best class ever!
we / us / ours.
they / them / him / her.
knows the thoughts and actions of one character.
doesn't know one single thing about what's going on.
is easily confused.
knows thoughts and actions of all characters
are big gossips, and should stop it.
tell facts through all characters.
tell facts through four characters.
tell facts through one character's thoughts.
know all and see all, just like your teacher.
know almost everything, just like your teacher.
report only the facts, but don't know feelings or thoughts.
know nothing and shouldn't be writing books.

questions.question: The exposition of a story is:

choices.answer: the setting (time and place) and background information.
the most exciting part of a story.
the same as the denouement.
the conflicts occurring before the climax.

questions.question: The rising action of a story occurs:

choices.answer: during conflicts that arise before the climax.
just before the resolution.
during the resolution.
as a result of the resolution.
comes before the exposition.
comes before the rising action.
happens when you trip.
happens right after the climax - things calm down.
a new kind of IMax theater.
the story from beginning to end.
the turning point or most intense moment of a story.
a summary of a story.
The same thing as a denouement.
A type of narration.
The main idea of a story.
A series of conflicts that lead up to a climax.

questions.question: The resolution of a story is:

choices.answer: the thesis statement.
the conclusive results of the climax.
the same as the exposition.
a character's moment of wild abandon.
interpretive dance.
a type of characterization.
the point of enlightenment or truth at the end of a story.
an irrelevant part of the story.
drawing cartoon characters.
character description.
acting out in class.
misinterpretation of a character.
never changes in the story.
sits around eating Doritos.
faces a series of conflicts and affects the resolution.
judges other characters.
is an antagonist.
is a protagonist.
plays a major role in a story.
faces few conflicts and does not affect the resolution.
is also a round character.
affects the resolution of  a story.
needs to use dryer sheets.
never changes over the course of conflicts.
gives great speeches.
changes his clothes.
changes mentally or emotionally in a story.
keeps the same attitude throughout the story.
show depth; they change or surprise the reader.
only appear sporadically in the story.
fight against the protagonist.
create a sense of finality.
show little depth and do not change (static).
sing badly, in flat tones.
need to eat more.
show depth and charisma.
are usually cows in a cartoon.
are types of characters found in certain genres.
can fly.
create the tone of a piece.
a villainous character.
always a nearly-perfect hero.
a weed.
the main character, with whom the reader empathizes.
tells what a character does.
tells how a character acts.
tells exactly what a character is.
tells nothing but lies.
tells about the animals in a narrative.
uses explicit explanations.
creates a sense of finality.
shows what a character does and says.
is expressed in about two words.
is expressed in a complete sentence.
is what a text is about.
is part of the rising action.
the topic of the paper.
an entire essay.
a symbol.
a life lesson given by the author, usually implicitly.
can set up a theme or mood of a piece.
one symbol in a piece of literature.
is repeated symbolic meanings in a piece of literature.
is something you keep on your mantle.
a hole in your pants.
a bad trait that could also be a strength gone awry.
created in a test tube.
a character trait in the protagonist that leads to downfall.

questions.question: The central/main idea of a text:

choices.answer: explains the most important idea about the topic.
is the same as the topic
is stated in a full sentence.
usually includes only 1 - 3 words
explains the main idea of the text.
gives hints or clues about future events.
solves a mystery.
puts a dark cloud on the text.
is a type of rhyme.
contains six syllables.
represents something else, such as an idea.
is a musical instrument.
is a cartoon of a human face.
means human characteristics given to animate beings.
an example is Winnie the Pooh.
is a type of conflict.
is the pitch with which characters sing or speak.
is the same thing as the mood.
comes solely from the exposition of a story.
is found in words/phrases used by authors to create a mood.
is how the reader feels from the tone the author sets.
is almost always eerie.
is found during the falling action.
is usually set to candlelight.
is either external or internal problems a character faces.
interrupts the narrative.
is found in the resolution.
is almost never found in stories.
usually non-existent in really bad movies.
a sacred burial ground on Native American territory.
always written in second person narratives.
the chain of events in a story.
an impolite reference.
a strand of the main plot that runs parallel to it.
a secondary plot.
played only by flat characters.
